elements.content: The novel iron selenidostannates [Fe(bipy)3]Sn4Se9·2H2O (1) and [Fe(bipy)3]2[Sn3Se7]2·bipy·2H2O (2) (bipy = bipyridine) were prepared by the reactions of Sn, Se, FeCl2·4H2O, bipy, and dien with/without KSCN under hydrothermal conditions (dien = diethylenetriamine). In 1, four SnSe5 units condense via edge sharing to form the novel 3-D framework selenidostannate ∞ 3[Sn4Se9 2–] containing an interpenetrating channel system. The [Fe(bipy)3]2+ cations are accommodated in the different channels according to the conformation of the [Fe(bipy)3]2+ cation. In 2, three SnSe5 units share edges to form a 2-D ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] layered anion, while two SnSe5 units and one SnSe4 unit are connected via edge sharing, forming a 1-D ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] chainlike anion. The ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–], [Fe(bipy)3]2+, bipy, and H2O species are embedded between the ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] layers. 2 is the first example of a selenidostannate constructed by both ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–]and ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] anions. The coexistence of 1-D ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] and 2-D ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] anions in 2 might support the possible reaction mechanism that the ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] anions are formed by condensation of the ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] chains. 1 and 2 exhibit band gaps at 1.43 and 2.01 eV, respectively.

In 2, three SnSe5 units share edges to form a 2-D ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2-] layered anion, while two SnSe5 units and one SnSe4 unit are connected via edge sharing, forming a 1-D ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2-] chainlike anion. The ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2-], [Fe(bipy)3]2+, bipy, and H2O species are embedded between the ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2-] layers. 2 is the first example of a selenidostannate constructed by both ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2-]and ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2-] anions. elements.content: Research on chalcogenidometalate compounds constructed by the composition of M/Ch (M = group 14 and 15 element; Ch = S, Se, Te) continues to be motivated both by their rich structural diversity based on the condensation of MCh4 or MCh5 primary building units via corner, edge or face sharing and by their potential applications as optical and electrical materials. Since Bedard et al. hydrothermally prepared microporous tin and germanium sulfides in aqueous amine solution in the late 1980s, the templating synthesis under mild hydro- or solvothermal conditions has been developed to be a versatile approach to the preparation of chalcogenidometalates. In the case of chalcogenidostannates, much effort in templating synthesis has led to a number of binary [Sn x Ch y ] n− anions with different dimensional structures ranging from oligomeric anions to one-dimensional (1-D) chains to two-dimensional (2-D) layers, using a variety of organic cations as structure-directing agents. The introduction of a transition metal (TM) into the binary Sn/Ch system has led to the formation of ternary [TM x Sn y Ch z ] m− anionic clusters or extended frameworks or chalcogenidostannates combined with TM organic complexes. The third types of tin chalcogenides are the lanthanide(Ln)-containing chalcogenidostannates with an organic Ln complex acting as the countercations. The additions of TM and Ln increase the structural diversity of the chalcogenidostannates. A number of ternary [TM x Sn y Ch z ] m− anions with complicated three-dimensional (3-D) open frameworks have been obtained, giving [Zn4Sn3S13 5–] n , [Zn4Sn3Se16 12–] n , {Sn[Zn4Sn4S17]6–} n , and {[Hg4(μ4-Ch)(SnCh4)3]6–} n (Ch = Se, Te), for example. However, the 3-D binary [Sn x Ch y ] n− anion is only observed in [BMIm]4Sn9Se20 (BMIm = 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium), which was prepared by ionothermal methods.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Research on chalcogenidometalate compounds constructed by the composition of M/Ch (M = group 14 and 15 element; Ch = S, Se, Te) continues to be motivated both by their rich structural diversity based on the condensation of MCh4 or MCh5 primary building units via corner, edge or face sharing and by their potential applications as optical and electrical materials. Since Bedard et al. hydrothermally prepared microporous tin and germanium sulfides in aqueous amine solution in the late 1980s, the templating synthesis under mild hydro- or solvothermal conditions has been developed to be a versatile approach to the preparation of chalcogenidometalates. In the case of chalcogenidostannates, much effort in templating synthesis has led to a number of binary [Sn x Ch y ] n- anions with different dimensional structures ranging from oligomeric anions to one-dimensional (1-D) chains to two-dimensional (2-D) layers, using a variety of organic cations as structure-directing agents. The introduction of a transition metal (TM) into the binary Sn/Ch system has led to the formation of ternary [TM x Sn y Ch z ] m- anionic clusters or extended frameworks or chalcogenidostannates combined with TM organic complexes. The third types of tin chalcogenides are the lanthanide(Ln)-containing chalcogenidostannates with an organic Ln complex acting as the countercations. The additions of TM and Ln increase the structural diversity of the chalcogenidostannates. A number of ternary [TM x Sn y Ch z ] m- anions with complicated three-dimensional (3-D) open frameworks have been obtained, giving [Zn4Sn3S13 5-] n , [Zn4Sn3Se16 12-] n , {Sn[Zn4Sn4S17]6-} n , and {[Hg4(μ4-Ch)(SnCh4)3]6-} n  (Ch = Se, Te), for example. However, the 3-D binary [Sn x Ch y ] n- anion is only observed in [BMIm]4Sn9Se20 (BMIm = 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium), which was prepared by ionothermal methods.

elements.content: On the other hand, the compositions and structures of chalcogenidometalates are influenced by hydrothermal or solvothermal reaction conditions. The templating synthesis is sensitive to the nature and size of structure-directing agents and a variety of reaction conditions, including reaction temperature, solvent, and the additional mineralizer. In the course of our study on the hydrothermal syntheses of chalcogenides in the presence of TM complexes, we prepared iron selenidostannates [Fe(bipy)3]Sn4Se9·2H2O (1) and [Fe(bipy)3]2[Sn3Se7]2·bipy·2H2O (2) under hydrothermal conditions. 1 contains a novel 3-D open-framework selenidostannate constructed by SnSe5 units. 2 is the first example of a selenidostannate composed of both a ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] chain and ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–]layer, although compounds containing single ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] or ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] anions have been prepared for decades.

The templating synthesis is sensitive to the nature and size of structure-directing agents and a variety of reaction conditions, including reaction temperature, solvent, and the additional mineralizer. In the course of our study on the hydrothermal syntheses of chalcogenides in the presence of TM complexes, we prepared iron selenidostannates [Fe(bipy)3]Sn4Se9⋅2H2O (1) and [Fe(bipy)3]2[Sn3Se7]2⋅bipy⋅2H2O (2) under hydrothermal conditions. 1 contains a novel 3-D open-framework selenidostannate constructed by SnSe5 units. 2 is the first example of a selenidostannate composed of both a ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2-] chain and ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2-]layer, although compounds containing single ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2-] or ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2-] anions have been prepared for decades.

elements.content: All starting chemicals were analytical grade and were used as received. Elemental analyses were conducted using an EA1110-CHNS-O elemental analyzer. Fourier infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna-IR 550 spectrometer using dry KBr disks over the 4000–400 cm–1 range. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were collected on a D/MAX-3C diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Room-temperature optical diffuse reflectance spectra of powder samples were obtained using a Shimadzu UV-3150 spectrometer. Absorption (α/S) data were calculated from reflectance using the Kubelka–Munk function α/S = (1 – R)2/2R. Thermal TG and DSC analyses were conducted on a SDT 2960 microanalyzer, and the samples were heated at a rate of 5 °C min–1 under a 100 mL min–1 nitrogen stream.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All starting chemicals were analytical grade and were used as received. Elemental analyses were conducted using an EA1110-CHNS-O elemental analyzer. Fourier infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna-IR 550 spectrometer using dry KBr disks over the 4000-400 cm-1 range. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were collected on a D/MAX-3C diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Room-temperature optical diffuse reflectance spectra of powder samples were obtained using a Shimadzu UV-3150 spectrometer. Absorption (α/S) data were calculated from reflectance using the Kubelka-Munk function α/S = (1 - R)2/2R. Thermal TG and DSC analyses were conducted on a SDT 2960 microanalyzer, and the samples were heated at a rate of 5 °C min-1 under a 100 mL min-1 nitrogen stream.

The sealed autoclave was heated to 145 °C for 6 days and then was cooled to ambient temperature. Black blocklike crystals of 1 were filtered off, washed with ethanol, and dried in air. elements.content: Data were collected on a Rigaku Saturn CCD diffractometer at 293(2) K using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) to a maximum 2θ value of 50.70°. The intensity data sets were collected with a ω-scan method and reduced with the CrystalClear program. An empirical absorption correction was applied for compounds 1 and 2 using the multiscan method. The structures were solved by direct methods using the program SHELXS-97 and were refined using a full-matrix least-squares refinement on F 2 using SHELXL-97. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were added geometrically and refined as a riding model. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules were not added. Technical details of data acquisition and selected refinement results are summarized in Table .

The reaction of Sn, Se, FeCl2·4H2O, KSCN, bipy, and dien in aqueous solution at 145 °C for 6 days produced black crystals of [Fe(bipy)3]Sn4Se9·2H2O (1). The reaction without KSCN under the same conditions afforded dark red blocklike crystals of [Fe(bipy)3]2[Sn3Se7]2·bipy·2H2O (2). The addition of 0.5–1.0 mmol of KSCN produced the same compound of 1. However, the role of KSCN is not yet clear. Compounds 1 and 2 can be obtained in the temperature range 145–170 °C. In all of the syntheses, the amine dien is needed. SnO2 or SnCl4 can be used instead of elemental Sn as the source for Sn4+ cations with yields of 52–68%. The bulk phase purity of compounds 1 and 2 was measured by a powder XRD study. The experimental PXRD patterns are similar to the simulated PXRD patterns on the basis of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data, respectively (Figures S1 and S2 in the ). In the IR spectra of 1 and 2 (Figures S3 and S4 in the ), absorption bands in the frequency range 3010–3065 cm–1 are due to the C–H vibrations of the aromatic ring hydrogen atoms of bipy ligands. The broad absorption bands in the range of 3450 and 3445 cm–1 are assigned to the O–H modes of H2O. The absorption bands in the range 1592–1438 cm–1 correspond to ring vibrations of the bipy ligand.

Results and Discussion

Syntheses

The reaction of Sn, Se, FeCl2⋅4H2O, KSCN, bipy, and dien in aqueous solution at 145 °C for 6 days produced black crystals of [Fe(bipy)3]Sn4Se9⋅2H2O (1). The reaction without KSCN under the same conditions afforded dark red blocklike crystals of [Fe(bipy)3]2[Sn3Se7]2⋅bipy⋅2H2O (2). The addition of 0.5-1.0 mmol of KSCN produced the same compound of 1. However, the role of KSCN is not yet clear. Compounds 1 and 2 can be obtained in the temperature range 145-170 °C. In all of the syntheses, the amine dien is needed. SnO2 or SnCl4 can be used instead of elemental Sn as the source for Sn4+ cations with yields of 52-68%. The bulk phase purity of compounds 1 and 2 was measured by a powder XRD study. The experimental PXRD patterns are similar to the simulated PXRD patterns on the basis of the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data, respectively (Figures S1 and S2 in the ). In the IR spectra of 1 and 2 (Figures S3 and S4 in the ), absorption bands in the frequency range 3010-3065 cm-1 are due to the C-H vibrations of the aromatic ring hydrogen atoms of bipy ligands. The broad absorption bands in the range of 3450 and 3445 cm-1 are assigned to the O-H modes of H2O. The absorption bands in the range 1592-1438 cm-1 correspond to ring vibrations of the bipy ligand.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the hexagonal space group R3c with 18 formula units in the unit cell. It consists of a [Fe(bipy)3]2+ complex cation, a 3-D polymeric ∞ 3[Sn4Se9 2–] anion, and two lattice water molecules. The Fe2+ ion is coordinated by three bipy ligands, forming a slightly distorted octahedral [Fe(bipy)3]2+ complex cation, as demonstrated by the axial and equatorial angles (Table ). The Fe–N bond lengths are similar to those observed in the reported Fe(II) complexes with a bipy ligand. The polymeric ∞ 3[Sn4Se9 2–] anion contains four crystallographically independent Sn4+ ions and nine Se2– ions. Each of the Sn4+ ions is coordinated to five Se2– anions at distances in the range 2.483(3)–2.828(2) Å, forming the SnSe5 primary building unit (PBU). All SnSe5 PBUs have a distorted-trigonal-bipyramidal symmetry geometry (Table ). The Sn–Se bond lengths and Se–Sn–Se angles are in accordance with those observed in the selenidostannates constructed by the SnSe5 PBU.

Three SnSe5 PBUs (containing Sn1, Sn2, and Sn3) share edges to form a Sn3Se10 secondary building unit (SBU), in which three Sn atoms are capped by a μ3-Se atom and are joined by three μ2-Se atoms to form a Sn3Se4 “semi-cube” (Figure a). Three Sn3Se10 SBUs are alternatively connected by three Sn(4)Se5 PBUs into a circular Sn12Se33 unit via edge sharing, which contains a 12-membered Sn6Se6 ring (Figure a). The Se2– anions adopt μ3-Se (Se1, Se3) and μ-Se (Se2, Se4–Se9) bridging coordination modes to the Sn4+ ions in the asymmetric [Sn4Se9]2– unit of compound 2. As shown in Figure b, each Sn12Se33 unit is further connected with six other Sn12Se33 units via edge sharing at Se8 and Se9 atoms. Three Sn12Se33 units (Figure b, shown in black) are located up the plane defined by the central Sn12Se33 unit, while three Sn12Se33 units (Figure b, shown in purple) are located down the plane. The planes of all the Sn12Se33 units are perpendicular to the [001] axis (Figure b). As a result, the Sn12Se33 units propagate to form the polymeric ∞ 3[Sn4Se9 2–]anion with a 3-D structure. The propagation of Sn12Se33 units generates a channel system, formed by connected helical chains of the linked SnSe5 PBUs as channel walls. The channels running along the [001] axis have a cross-sectional diameter of 8.3 Å, and each Sn12Se33 unit is surrounded by six such channels (Figures a and a). The channels are formed by helical chainlike SnSe5 linkages along the [001] axis. The left-handed (Figure b) and right-handed (Figure c) helices occur alternately around the Sn12Se33 units. [Fe(bipy)3]2+ ions and H2O molecules are located in the channels (Figures S5 and S6 in the ). The [Fe(bipy)3]2+ ions in the channels formed by right-handed helices are in the Δ conformation, while the [Fe(2,2′-bipy)3]2+ ions in the left-handed channels are in the Λ conformation (). Other channels run along the [100], [010], and [101] directions and have cross-sectional dimensions of 14.9 × 5.8 (in the [100] and [010] directions) and 17.9 × 9.6 Å2, respectively (Figure b,c).

elements.content: The high tendency for copolymerization of the SnSe4 and SnSe5 PBUs via corner, edge, or face sharing had led to a series of binary selenidostannates with different compositions and structures ranging from discrete anions to infinite chains to two-dimensional sheets, depending on the structure-directing agents or countercations used in the syntheses. However, selenidostannates with three-dimensional constructs are very rare. The compound [BMIm]4Sn9Se20, which was prepared using an organic cation as counterion under ionothermal conditions, is the only example of a selenidostannate containing a 3-D framework. The anion is composed of both SnSe4 and SnSe5 PBUs via edge and face sharing. The 3-D selenidostannate constructed by a sole SnSe5 trigonal bipyramid has not been observed before. 1 represents the first 3-D framework selenidostannate constructed by a SnSe5 trigonal bipyramid and containing TM complex countercations. Thus, the formation of a 3-D selenidostannate anion based on the SnSe5 trigonal bipyramids in 1 is unique. It is worth noting that the compound A2Sn4Se9·H2O (A = Rb, Cs) exhibits a structure completely different from that of 1, even though it has the same anionic composition as that of 1. The compound A2Sn4Se9·H2O consists of a ∞ 2[Sn4Se9 2–] layered anion that is constructed by the tetrahedral SnSe4 PBUs.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c with 4 formula units in the unit cell. It consists of two [Fe(bipy)3]2+ complex cations, a two-dimensional ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] anion, a one-dimensional ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] anion, a free bipy molecule, and two lattice water molecules. Both Fe(1)2+ and Fe(2)2+ are coordinated by three bipy ligands, forming octahedral [Fe(bipy)3]2+ complexes with a structure similar to that of the Fe(II) complex cation in 1 (Tables S1 and S2 in the ). Compound 2 contains 6 crystallographically independent Sn4+ ions and 14 Se2– ions. Except for the Sn(4)4+ ion, which is in a tetrahedral coordination sphere, the other five Sn4+ ions are coordinated to five Se2– anions, forming SnSe5 trigonal-bipyramidal PBUs. The Sn–Se bond lengths of the SnSe5 units are in the range 2.512(2)–2.8273(19) Å (Table ) and are in accordance with those observed in 1, except for the Sn(6)–Se(9) bond, which has a longer length of 3.136(2) Å (). In 2, the Sn–Se bond lengths of the SnSe4 (Sn–Se = 2.408(2)–2.599(2) Å) unit are in the lower range of the equatorial Sn–Se bond lengths of SnSe5 (Sn–Se = 2.5125(18)–2.631(2) Å) but are obviously shorter than those of the axial Sn–Se bond lengths of SnSe5 (Sn–Se = 2.6751(19)–2.8273(19) Å) (Table and Table S2 in the ).

elements.content: Three SnSe5 PBUs (containing Sn1, Sn2, and Sn3) share edges to form a Sn3Se10 SBU containing a Sn3Se4 “semicube”. Each Sn3Se10 SBU is connected to three other Sn3Se10 SBUs via edge sharing (at Se6 and Se7) to form the layered ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] anion (Figure a). As a result, the interconnection of the Sn3Se10 SBUs generates a honeycomb structure containing 24-membered Sn12Se12 rings in the ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] layers (Figure b). The Sn12Se12 rings are formed by six Sn3Se4 semicubes interlinked by 12 μ2-Se atoms. Two SnSe5 PBUs (containing Sn5 and Sn6) and one SnSe4 PBU are joined end to end via edge sharing to form a Sn3Se9 SBU, which also contains a Sn3Se4 semicube. The Sn3Se9 SBUs are connected via edge sharing at Se12 and Se13 into a one-dimensional ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] chain (Figure b). The ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] chains run parallel to the [010] axis (Figure a). The ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] chains, [Fe(bipy)3]2+ cations, H2O, and free bipy molecules are embedded between the ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] layers, which are perpendicular to the [100] axis (Figure a). The [Fe(2)(bipy)3]2+ cations are located at both sides of the ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] chain (Figure S7 in the ), while the [Fe(1)(bipy)3]2+ cations suspend up and down the honeycomb holes of the ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] layer with a pyridine ring inserting into the hole (Figure S8 in the ).

elements.content: Two different modifications are observed for the ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] layered anions. The ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] layer in 2 contains a 24-membered Sn12Se12 “rectangular ring” with cross sectional dimensions of 13.478 × 10.184 Å (Figure S9 in the ). Several chalcogenidostannates containing the ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] layered anions have been prepared to date using alkali-metal cations, organic cations, and TM complex cations as the counterions. All of the 2-D anions in these reported chalcogenidostannates have the structures and connections similar to those of the ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] anion in 2, but they possess the “round ring” Sn12Se12. The ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] anion in [Fe(phen)3]Sn3Se7·1.25H2O, for example, contains 24-membered round rings with a diameter of 11.305 Å (). In the∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] anion, each Sn3Se4 semicube is connected with three other Sn3Se4 units via three double μ-Se bridges. The three dihedral angles around the three double μ-Se bridges in the ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] anion of [Fe(phen)3]Sn3Se7·1.25H2O are identical and are equal to −1.82°. However, the corresponding angles of the ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] anion in 2 are 0.0, 9.52(3), and 10.10(3)° (Table S2 in the ), which causes formation of the rectangular Sn12Se12 ring.

elements.content: The striking feature of 2 is the coexistence of 1-D ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] and 2-D ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] anions in one compound. The ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] layered anions have been commonly observed as salts of a variety of cations. Sheldrick proposed that the ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] layered anion would be formed by condensation of the single ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] chains via a concerted nucleophilic attack of the terminal Se atoms on the tetrahedral Sn atoms of the adjacent ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] chains. However, the ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] chain has not been isolated from the synthetic solutions, except for the lone example of (Et4N)2Sn3Se7, which was prepared in CH3OH solution using (Et4N)I as the structure-directing agent under solvothermal conditions. Recently, a [Sn3Se7 2–]∞ double chain has been ionothermally prepared, which is regarded as a possible “intermediate product” of the reaction pathway from a single chain to a layer. The coexistence of the ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] and ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] anions in a single compound of 2 is another example to strongly support the proposed reaction mechanism from ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] chains to a ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] layer.

elements.content: The UV–vis reflectance spectra of the title compounds were measured on powder samples at room temperature. The absorption data from the reflectance spectra by the Kubelka–Munk function demonstrate that compound 1 exhibits a steep absorption edge with a band gap (E g) at 1.43 eV, which is smaller than that of the 3-D [BMIm]4[Sn9Se20]. Compound 2 shows an absorption edge with band gaps at 2.01 eV (Figure ). The band gap is comparable to that of the Fe selenidostannates [Fe(phen)3]Sn3Se7·1.25H2O (E g = 1.97 eV), containing a ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] anionic layer. The broad absorption at 4.30 eV (288.5 nm) may be attributed to the intraligand π → π* transition occurring in bipy.

elements.content: The thermal stabilities of the title compounds were investigated by TG-DSC methods under a nitrogen atmosphere in the temperature range 25–500 °C. The TGA curve shows that compound 1 decomposes in two steps with mass losses of 2.7% in the first step and 27.1% in the second step (Figure S10 in the ). The mass losses are in agreement with complete removals of the H2O molecules (theoretical mass loss 2.1%) and bipy (theoretical mass loss 26.8%), respectively. The decomposition process is accompanied by two endothermic signals in the DSC curve with peak temperatures at 142 and 323 °C. Compound 2 also decomposes in a two-step process. It loses two H2O molecules and one free bipy molecule (mass loss theoretical 6.3%, observed 5.8%) between 120 and 270 °C in the first step. In the second step, it removes all bipy ligands with a total mass loss of 30.1% (theoretical mass loss 30.6%) between 275 and 375 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Properties

The thermal stabilities of the title compounds were investigated by TG-DSC methods under a nitrogen atmosphere in the temperature range 25-500 °C. The TGA curve shows that compound 1 decomposes in two steps with mass losses of 2.7% in the first step and 27.1% in the second step (Figure S10 in the ). The mass losses are in agreement with complete removals of the H2O molecules (theoretical mass loss 2.1%) and bipy (theoretical mass loss 26.8%), respectively. The decomposition process is accompanied by two endothermic signals in the DSC curve with peak temperatures at 142 and 323 °C. Compound 2 also decomposes in a two-step process. It loses two H2O molecules and one free bipy molecule (mass loss theoretical 6.3%, observed 5.8%) between 120 and 270 °C in the first step. In the second step, it removes all bipy ligands with a total mass loss of 30.1% (theoretical mass loss 30.6%) between 275 and 375 °C.

elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, the novel selenidostannates 1 containing a 3-D ∞ 3[Sn4Se9 2-] open framework, and 2 containing mixed 2-D ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2-] and 1-D ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2-] anions were first prepared using the [Fe(bipy)3]2+ complex cation formed in situ as a structure-directing agent under solvothermal conditions. The synthesis of 2 confirms the existence of 1-D ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2-] and 2-D ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2-] anions in a single compound, which might support the proposed reaction pathway that the ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2-] anions would be formed by condensation of the single ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2-] chains.

cln_elements.content:
The novel iron selenidostannates [Fe(bipy)3]Sn4Se9·2H2O (1) and [Fe(bipy)3]2[Sn3Se7]2·bipy·2H2O (2) (bipy = bipyridine) were prepared by the reactions of Sn, Se, FeCl2·4H2O, bipy, and dien with/without KSCN under hydrothermal conditions (dien = diethylenetriamine). In 1, four SnSe5 units condense via edge sharing to form the novel 3-D framework selenidostannate ∞ 3[Sn4Se9 2–] containing an interpenetrating channel system. The [Fe(bipy)3]2+ cations are accommodated in the different channels according to the conformation of the [Fe(bipy)3]2+ cation. In 2, three SnSe5 units share edges to form a 2-D ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] layered anion, while two SnSe5 units and one SnSe4 unit are connected via edge sharing, forming a 1-D ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] chainlike anion. The ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–], [Fe(bipy)3]2+, bipy, and H2O species are embedded between the ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] layers. 2 is the first example of a selenidostannate constructed by both ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–]and ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] anions. The coexistence of 1-D ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] and 2-D ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] anions in 2 might support the possible reaction mechanism that the ∞ 2[Sn3Se7 2–] anions are formed by condensation of the ∞ 1[Sn3Se7 2–] chains. 1 and 2 exhibit band gaps at 1.43 and 2.01 eV, respectively.

Thermal Properties

The thermal stabilities of the title compounds were investigated by TG-DSC methods under a nitrogen atmosphere in the temperature range 25–500 °C. The TGA curve shows that compound 1 decomposes in two steps with mass losses of 2.7% in the first step and 27.1% in the second step (Figure S10 in the ). The mass losses are in agreement with complete removals of the H2O molecules (theoretical mass loss 2.1%) and bipy (theoretical mass loss 26.8%), respectively. The decomposition process is accompanied by two endothermic signals in the DSC curve with peak temperatures at 142 and 323 °C. Compound 2 also decomposes in a two-step process. It loses two H2O molecules and one free bipy molecule (mass loss theoretical 6.3%, observed 5.8%) between 120 and 270 °C in the first step. In the second step, it removes all bipy ligands with a total mass loss of 30.1% (theoretical mass loss 30.6%) between 275 and 375 °C.

metadata.title:
Novel One‑, Two‑, and Three-Dimensional
Selenidostannates Templated by Iron(II) Complex Cation
